Rabies cases on the rise in northeastern Thailand

Dr. Tawichai of the 9th Disease Prevention and Control Department revealed on February 9 that there has been an increase in rabies infections in northeastern Thailand, with a total of 74 people infected.

So far this year (from last October to September this year), a total of 74 people have been found positive for rabies in the northeastern provinces of Surin and Buri Ram, 67 in Surin and 7 in Buri Ram.
Everyone has had a rabies vaccination in the past.
The doctor is urging people to get vaccinated for rabies with their pets and to avoid contact with the saliva of animals that may be infected.
Rabies is not only transmitted by dogs, but also by cats and bats to humans.
If a person gets infected and shows symptoms, almost 100% of them will die, but vaccination before symptoms can prevent death.

FUJI (headquarters in Chiryu City), which handles the production and sales of electronic component mounting robots and machine tools, has started developing a system to prevent children being left in cars.
A system that attaches a motion sensor to the inside of a car, and sends notifications to the phone or chat when it detects movement.
We are currently conducting a field test using our own vehicles.
While terrible accidents happen with car seats, keep your child safe.
Currently, Chiryu City is conducting a trial using two buses to pick up children for their own after-school English conversation school for children, "teracoya THANK (TERACOYA SANKU)".
Motion sensors that detect movement by sensing the temperature difference between people and their surroundings are installed in the ceiling of the car at three locations.
When the vehicle engine is off and the door is closed, after a certain time has passed, if it detects movement, it will automatically send a notification of the warning.
By linking engine and door status and information, it is possible to prevent false alarms as much as possible.
Warning notifications are broadcast through the cloud.
It's also used to display on your computer or smartphone chat, as well as calling the number you registered.
They allow you to register multiple addresses so you don't miss anything.
The clinical trial will continue until the end of February.
"While conducting the experiment, we were able to see other issues around the system," said Kanaya, the chief of the second section of the Innovation Promotion Department.
For example, they were able to tackle a variety of issues related to school buses, such as creating an environment that allows drivers to focus on driving.
You must surrender to the Power before you can control it.”
The development of a system to prevent abandonment was triggered by a series of accidents involving buses that left passengers stranded all over the country.
A suggestion was made by an employee with children, asking if there was anything that could be done to ensure the safety of the children.
We decided to develop the know-how we have cultivated through our business in factory automation, IoT (Internet of Things) and sensors, and information management, to create new value.
Fujis non-slip system is selling on ease of use.
The sensor can be installed just by pinning it to the ceiling.
It is easy to attach to a welcome car, so it will lower the hurdle for introduction and aim for widespread use.
In the future, we will consider productization while relying on cooperation with childcare centers and kindergartens.

The cat-shaped serving robot is being introduced at the Fukui Station branch of "Iwa-Shio Aged Jingisukan Bon".
Cute expressions and so on are popular with families = Fukui Prefecture, Fukui City, the top 2nd district
In Fukui Prefecture, where the food industry is struggling with a labor shortage, the introduction of food delivery robots that bring food to the table is gaining momentum.
Robots' friendly expressions and other features are popular with families, helping with cost-cutting and contactless service to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.
From restaurant operators and related parties, voices are heard saying, "It will be difficult for local restaurants to secure employees and apprentices, and the spread of meal robots will continue."
"Jin, Jin, Jin-Gisukan♪".
A robot with a cat's face on its screen plays light music as it glides smoothly through the restaurant, displaying food on its tray.
When you arrive at your table, they talk to you, like "I've brought your food, nyaa."
In August 2022, the "Iwansen Jingisukan Bon Ton Fukui Ekimae Store" in Fukui City's 2nd district, one of the city's major restaurants, introduced a cat-shaped serving robot.

A robot waits near the kitchen to pick up the food, the customer places the food on the table and presses the table number on the screen, the robot then autonomously drives to the table to deliver the food.
AI voice functions and more are built in, so the cat reacts when you touch it and has a range of facial expressions that appear on the screen.
The "Bonta Group" that manages the restaurant has introduced the robot in two restaurants including this one.

Saito Shinji, president of the company, said that the reason for introducing it is "labor shortage", and emphasized that it is one of the measures to improve productivity by reducing personnel and digital transformation (DX).
The labor cost as a percentage of sales is usually around 30%, but it can be reduced by 21-22% with the introduction.

Robots also have the role of collecting used plates from customers, which is connected to the efficiency of the clean-up, and adds that "it's fun for families and children, and has promotional effects."
In Shinpo-cho, Araki, Fukui City, the barbecue and hot pot restaurant "Rokuganeyama Fukui-ten" also introduced a meal-serving robot in August 2020.

Son San, the president of Eunguk, a company that operates convenience stores, said, "We have been unable to recruit employees or albaits. I thought it would be absolutely necessary to solve the problem of personnel shortage."
At the Fukui store, they separate the area where the employees serve food and the area where the robots deliver food, and operate them.
The cost of renting a robot is the same as the salary of one person in Albay.
In an effort to cut costs, the store is also introducing a tablet-based ordering system and considering self-checkout.

According to the Fukui Prefectural Labor Bureau, the effective recruitment ratio for the December 2022 job categories shows that "customer service" jobs such as restaurants are 6.94 times higher than the average, indicating a shortage of workers.

The manager of a net system that sells meal delivery robots (Fukui City, Koguchi Chuo 2-chome) said, "The shortage of manpower in restaurants in Fukui Prefecture has become more serious due to the influence of the new coronavirus, and there are many inquiries about introducing robots."
"I think that the spread of feeding robots will make it even more difficult to secure employees for local suburban stores," said Hoshiyama.

Last year, the author published a book that covers everything from the procedures and writing styles for wills and inheritance lists to family trees, which proved popular and led to many people asking for copies for themselves.
In the prefecture, there are seminars on how to write an obituary and how to prepare for death in various locations, and "end of life" has become a fixed concept for the citizens.
Echizen town's Ending Note is 35 pages.
The 5th chapter starts with a review of your history and goes on to record your current health status, assets, future care, end-of-life medical wishes, funeral and burial preferences, etc.
There is also a section where you can write down things you want to do in the rest of your life and messages to your loved ones.
I say 35 pages but it feels like it could break, you don’t need to fill all the pages.
What would you most want to write down about your family?
The important thing is to make your goal clear.
In bookstores and such, there are various types of notes that are sold to suit the purpose, and you can start writing easily where you can write.
The term "death by job hunting" was coined in 2009.
In 2011, two years after the Great East Japan Earthquake, occurred.
It is said that many people have come to face the reality that "death comes suddenly" and more people are preparing for their own end and end-of-life.
More than 10 years have passed since then.
The new coronavirus, which has hit the world, is still not under control.
With the Russian invasion of Ukraine and other factors, prices have skyrocketed, and this winter's electricity prices are unbelievable.
On the other hand, wages are not rising as fast as prices, and many people are worried about falling behind.
On the other hand, in the past, funeral expenses, care expenses, and grave management, which could be shared with neighbors and relatives, are now a time when only children are common.
Another dilemma is that while life expectancy has increased dramatically in recent years, the risk of dementia and need for care increases as we age.
I would like to keep in mind that the background of temporary death is also a society where anxiety is increasing.
Anyway, I think everyone would want to avoid putting too much burden on their partner or children.
The phrase "dying with dignity" is a popular keyword for Ending Note, but it can't be too self-centered.
I don't want to write a will with my hopes and wishes, I want to talk to my family about it and be prepared for that time.

At the graduation ceremony, it was shown that wearing masks is not necessary for children and teachers = February 10, Toda City, Saitama Prefecture
On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that children should not wear masks at graduation ceremonies.
"It's difficult to keep students apart, and we're wondering how to deal with it. There are students who feel uneasy about taking off their masks," said the principal of a large junior high school.
After news reports about students wearing masks at graduation ceremonies, the topic has been a hot topic among teachers.
Meanwhile, one elementary school principal said, "If the country decides not to wear it, they won't wear it. It's not realistic to respond to anything other than singing."

At this graduation ceremony, the school recognized the participation of students who had withdrawn, and resumed the graduation song sung by the graduates, and there were also movements to explore the easing of measures in some parts of the prefecture's schools.
In the prefecture, the prefectural high schools will hold their graduation ceremonies in early March, and the public elementary and junior high schools will hold theirs in mid-March.
The prefectural and municipal boards of education are waiting for an official notice from the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology to decide how to respond.
There have also been calls for caution over the Ministry of Education's decision to no longer require the wearing of masks in school education activities from the new semester this spring.

"Suddenly, on a certain day, children will be confused if we don't wear masks. It's natural that more children will start to take them off after we first decided to make it optional," said the elementary school principal.

On February 10, the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology decided that starting in April, masks will not be required in school education activities in accordance with the new government guidelines.
Singing, physical education classes, and club activities will be held without masks.

In the meantime, we will ask for infection prevention measures in accordance with the current health management manual, and we will inform the Education Committee and schools of the points to note from April onwards.

At graduation ceremonies for elementary, middle, and high schools, as well as universities, throughout the 2022 academic year, graduates, teachers, and students attending will be required to wear masks.

NPO "Kokoro no Hibiku Bunko/Henshu Kyoku" self-published book "Dear Prime Minister, A Lifesaver from Tōjinbō"
"Dear Prime Minister, from Tōjinbō, a breakwater for life" I self-published my 10th book with this title.
All the newspapers in the country have taken it up, and we have received a lot of feedback from readers.

The purpose of publishing this book is to share the insights of those who have planned to commit suicide on the "social and structural" environment that is the cause of suicide in Japan, and to create a society where people can live with "a sense of belonging" by sharing this with everyone.

We have been patrolling the cliffs of Tōjinbō, Fukui Prefecture, a well-known suicide spot, for 18 years and 10 months to prevent suicide, and we continue to support activities to find and protect those who are planning suicide and help them start over.

This book summarizes the issues raised by the 784 people (2/6 currently) who have been protected so far, and presents seven items to the Prime Minister as necessary measures to prevent suicide at the national level.
(1) Suicide prevention is a "life-saving" activity.
(2) Behind suicide, there are "human rights violations".
(3) The suicides are victims of social and structural organized crime.
(4) Administrative agencies are treating citizens who live outside their jurisdiction as "outsiders" and treating them coldly.
(5) They drug up people with depression and other mental illnesses and if they commit suicide, they call it an "accident".
(6) The "duty of care" is being forgotten in high-risk suicide areas as commercialism takes over.
(7) The teachings of new religious organizations that cannot be scientifically proven are fraudulent, and threatening future curses and demanding offerings is coercion.
The religious organizations that are committing these "fraud and coercion" crimes should be publicly excluded.

So, we have received a lot of feedback from people who have purchased the book, and some of the feedback that has resonated with us is, "I was inspired by the strong mentalities of those who are involved in this activity," or "The former police officer's appearance is that of a police officer," or "He is a bodhisattva who lives by helping others, even though he is not one himself." Everyone is unique.
I hope we can live in a society where we can enjoy our lives with the lives we have been given.
I have a lot of respect and gratitude for the staff who are working so hard to help people who are suffering as much as they would wish to die.
I think this is a very abusive activity to both body and mind, but please take care of yourself and continue to speak out.
thank you very much.

Introduction to pioneers of plant research, including data on Mount Hayachine, at the city's comprehensive cultural property center exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online | Iwate Nichinichi Shimbun

An exhibition that pays tribute to the pioneers who laid the foundation for the study of the alpine plants of Mount Hayachine, known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the Hanamaki City Ohasama Integrated Cultural Asset Center until the 12th.
This book collects 124 valuable samples and documents collected by predecessors, and introduces the footprints of predecessors in the research of plants on Mount Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mount Hayachine began with the arrival of Russian plant researcher Karl Ivanovich Maximowicz (1827-91) during the end of the Edo period, and with Chonosuke Sugawa (1842-1925), a native of Fujisawa who collected plants under the guidance of Maximowicz.
Maximovitch, who was not allowed to freely walk around the country for foreigners, asked Sugawara to collect and continued research for three years based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.
After returning from Maximoum, Sukawa continued to support research and presented the unique plants of Mount Hayachine, such as "Himekosazura", "Nambutouuchisou", and "Miyamayamabukishouma".

After that, the modern plant taxonomist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published Bistorta hayachinensis, Cohabentusmeckesia, Draba japonica, and Katouhakobe, which he discovered and named himself on Mt. Ashio in 1903 (Meiji 36) and 1905 (Meiji 38), respectively.
From the display materials, you can see that many researchers have discovered precious alpine plants.

We also introduce Sugimura Masanori (1874-1948), the principal of the Flowery Elementary School who conducted plant research while accompanying the survey on natural monuments preservation in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-88), who worked at the Mount Ōhasama Museum and was involved in the publication of "Plants of Mount Ōhasama

"There are many studies and connections behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine. We can connect researchers from all over the country who are doing research on the same topic," says Yoshida Toshihide, a researcher at the same center.

The exhibition is divided into four chapters. The first chapter is about the belief and history of Mount Hayachine, the second chapter is about German geologists who built the foundation of Japanese geology, Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927) and others, and the third chapter is about the characteristics of Mount Hayachine from the perspective of geology, with a spotlight on it.

Discussions on introducing renewable energy and setting goals Amami Airport 2nd Decarbonization Promotion Council | Society & Economy | Naha Shimbun
Promotion council for decarbonization of Amami Airport: Discussions on the decarbonization of Amami Airport = 9th, Kasaricho, Amami

In order to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at Amami Airport (in Amami City, Setouchi-cho), a "Promotion Council for Decarbonization at Amami Airport" (Chairman: Ando Tatsuo, Director of the Construction Bureau of the Oshima Subprefecture, members: 13 people) held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All directors, including online, attended.
We discussed the setting of decarbonization targets and the introduction of renewable energy, with solar power as the main focus.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a target to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions of each airport by 46% or more (compared to 2005) within 30 years, as it aims to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050.
The council held its first meeting in November last year and is aiming to be the first of the prefecture's other six island airports to draw up a plan.
The second meeting will be closed to the public, as was the first.
After the meeting, Ando, the chairman, who was interviewed, said that the meeting confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions from the airport.
The government has been pushing for talks in line with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' guidelines to set targets and introduce renewable energy, the sources said.
According to the information provided, the amount of CO2 emissions from the same airport facilities and vehicles in the base year of 2013 was 1,476 tons (excluding aircraft).

Of these, emissions from seven facilities including airport terminal buildings amount to 1,321 tons, accounting for about 90 percent, followed by 84 tons of aviation lighting and 71 tons of airport vehicles.
The council is discussing reducing emissions from these facilities and vehicles.
Chairman Ando said, "We are at the point of passing through. The direction of the members is in agreement, and first, I want to make sure we have a solid grasp of the interim report."
In the future, we will draft a plan to promote the project after hearing opinions on the draft interim report at the third meeting and the draft final report at the fourth meeting.
